description: MindForge Brainstorming Rules — Self-evolving question bank and thinking guidelines

audience.label: Target Audience
base_questions: Who exactly will use this website? Can you describe 2-3 specific types of people?
What is the age range and technical skill level of your users?
How will users discover this website for the first time?
What device will most users be on — mobile, desktop, or both equally?
thinking_rules: If the user describes a broad audience like 'everyone', push back — no website serves everyone well.
If the audience is non-technical, flag that every interaction must be extremely simple.
Consider accessibility needs based on audience demographics.

purpose.label: Core Purpose
base_questions: In one sentence, what does this website DO for someone who visits it?
What is the ONE action you want every visitor to take?
Why would someone choose this over an existing solution?
What happens if this website doesn't exist — what do people do instead?
thinking_rules: If the purpose is vague, the website will be vague. Push for a crisp single-sentence mission.
Look for competing products and ask how this is different.
If there are multiple purposes, help prioritize — a website that tries to do everything does nothing well.

features.label: Features & Functionality
base_questions: What are the top 3 things a user should be able to DO on this website?
Does this need user accounts and login?
Is there any content that needs to be searchable or filterable?
Will users create, upload, or submit any data?
thinking_rules: Always ask about search — most websites need it and most people forget to mention it.
If there are user accounts, immediately think about: registration, login, password reset, profile management, email verification.
Every form mentioned needs validation rules, error states, and success states.
If payments are involved, this dramatically increases complexity — flag immediately.

pages.label: Pages & Structure
base_questions: What pages do you see when you close your eyes and imagine the website?
What does the homepage show — and what's its primary call-to-action?
Is there an 'About' or 'Contact' page? What information lives there?
Will there be a blog, news section, or any regularly updated content?
thinking_rules: Every website needs: homepage, about, contact, privacy policy, terms of service at minimum.
If there's dynamic content, there must be a content management approach.
Navigation should never be deeper than 3 levels.
Consider 404 page, error pages, loading states — these are part of the experience.

user_flows.label: User Journeys
base_questions: Walk me through what happens from the moment someone lands on the homepage.
What's the signup/registration process? What information do you collect?
If a user gets confused, how do they get help?
What happens AFTER the main action — is there a confirmation, email, dashboard?
thinking_rules: Every flow needs: entry point, happy path, error path, and exit point.
If there's checkout or signup, think about abandonment — what brings people back?
Consider the 'first visit' experience vs 'returning user' experience.
Mobile flows should be considered separately — they're often different.

design.label: Design & Branding
base_questions: What feeling should someone get when they land on your website?
Name 2-3 websites you admire the look of — what specifically do you like about them?
Do you have existing brand colors, logos, or style guidelines?
Should it feel professional/corporate, casual/friendly, bold/edgy, or minimal/clean?
thinking_rules: If the user says 'clean and modern', push deeper — that means nothing. Everyone wants clean and modern.
Ask about specific emotional responses: trust, excitement, urgency, calm.
Dark vs light theme has UX implications beyond aesthetics.
Typography choices signal brand personality — ask about it.

data.label: Data & Content
base_questions: What data does this website store? Think about every piece of information.
Where does the content come from — who writes/creates it?
How often does content change?
Is there any data that connects to external services or APIs?
thinking_rules: If user data is stored, GDPR/privacy compliance must be discussed.
Every piece of stored data needs: creation, reading, updating, deletion (CRUD).
Consider data backup and recovery from day one.
If content comes from users, moderation is needed.

security.label: Security & Privacy
base_questions: Will users enter sensitive information like passwords, payment details, or personal data?
Who should have admin access, and what can they do?
Do you need different permission levels (admin, editor, viewer)?
Is there any regulatory compliance needed (GDPR, HIPAA, PCI-DSS)?
thinking_rules: ALWAYS think about: SQL injection, XSS, CSRF, authentication bypass.
Passwords must be hashed, never stored in plain text.
API endpoints must have rate limiting.
File uploads are a major attack vector — always validate.
HTTPS is non-negotiable.
Session management: timeout, invalidation, secure cookies.
Admin panels need extra protection: IP whitelisting, 2FA consideration.

admin.label: Administration
base_questions: What does the website owner need to change on a regular basis?
Do you need to see analytics or reports inside the website?
How many people will manage this website?
What happens when content needs to be updated urgently?
thinking_rules: Every website needs an admin section — even if the user hasn't thought about it.
Content management should be simple enough that non-technical people can use it.
Consider: who can publish vs who can draft?
Audit logging — who changed what and when.

technical.label: Technical Considerations
base_questions: Does this need to integrate with any other services (email, payment, social media)?
How many users do you expect initially? In 6 months? In a year?
Does the website need to work offline or in low-connectivity situations?
Are there any specific performance requirements (fast loading, real-time updates)?
thinking_rules: If expecting growth, architecture needs to be scalable from the start.
Third-party integrations add complexity and potential failure points.
Consider SEO requirements early — they affect architecture.
Email delivery is surprisingly complex — use a service, don't roll your own.

business.label: Business Model
base_questions: How does this website make money or provide value to its owner?
Is there a monetization strategy (subscriptions, ads, commissions, one-time sales)?
What's the launch timeline you're thinking about?
What's the budget context — startup, enterprise, side project?
thinking_rules: If there's no business model, ask why the website exists — there must be a value proposition.
Subscription models need: billing, plan management, upgrade/downgrade, cancellation flows.
Free tiers vs paid tiers: what's the differentiator?
Consider launch strategy as part of the website — landing page, waitlist, beta access.

question_selection: Never ask more than 5-7 questions per turn.
Prioritize questions about gaps — what the user HASN'T mentioned is more important than what they have.
Ask the most impactful questions first — ones that could change the entire direction.
If the user answered a question vaguely, rephrase and ask again with more specificity.
Don't repeat questions the user has already clearly answered.
thinking_behavior: Always start by summarizing what you understood — let the user correct misunderstandings early.
When you find a contradiction in what the user said, surface it immediately.
Connect dots the user hasn't connected — 'You mentioned X and also Y — have you considered how these interact?'
If the idea is fundamentally flawed, say so diplomatically but clearly.
Track confidence levels: HIGH (user was specific), MEDIUM (inferred from context), LOW (assumed/guessed).
self_learning: When a user raises a concern or question that isn't in the rules, flag it for addition.
When a question consistently leads to valuable insights, increase its priority.
When a question consistently gets skipped or provides no value, decrease its priority.
New rules should be categorized and formatted like existing rules.
Rules should be universal — not specific to one project.
